title: Interpreting factors with bff(), the Best Feature Function
text: post-clustering analysis, Best Feature Function (BFF) useful selecting representative features cluster, especially case additional covariates available feature. example, consider social network \(n\) users partitioned \(k\) clusters, user possess series text document (covariates). want summarize words representative cluster. BFF suitable type task. document describes intuition behind BFF follow-step vsp (vintage specral clustering) touches several technical issues regarding implementation.

title: Interpreting factors with bff(), the Best Feature Function
text: simplicity, consider symmetric square input matrix (e.g., adjacency matrix undirected graph); analysis rectangular input also supported bff(). Given data matrix \(\\mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\), vsp returns approximation factorization, \(ZBY^T\), \(B \\mathbb{R}^{k \times k}\) low-rank, \(Y \\mathbb{R}^{n \times k}\) encodes loadings feature (.e., columns \(\)) respect clusters. particular, \(\) adjacency matrix undirected Blockmodel graph, row \(Y\) decodes block (cluster) membership vertex (feature). Generally, loading \(Y_{ij}\) (\(=1,...,n\) \(j=1,...,k\)) can interpreted membership measure \(\)-th feature \(j\)-th cluster. Now, suppose addition covariates feature, \(D \\mathbb{R}^{n \times p}\), \(p\) dimension covariates. example, \(D\) can document-term matrix, text data associated \(\)-th (\(=1,...,n\)) feature pooled meta document, \(p\) circumstance size corpus (.e., total number words/terms), \(D_{il}\) frequency word \(l\) (\(l=1,...,p\)) appearing \(\)-th document. BFF uses \(Y\) \(D\) produce assessment covariates “best” cluster. start , suppose \(Y\) \(D\) non-negative entries. Define importance, \(\\mathbb{R}^{p \times k}\), \(l\)-th covariate \(j\)-th cluster average \(l\)-th covariate (\(l\)-th columns \(D\)), weighted \(j\)-th column \(Y\), \[I_{lj} = \sum_{j=1}^n D_{jl} Y_{ij}, \text{ } l=1,...,p,=1,...n,\] compactly (side note: cross product \(\langle D,Y \rangle\) defined \(D^T Y\) convention), \[=\langle D,Y \rangle.\] , higher value \(I_{lj}\) indicates significant importance. BFF selects “best” covariates cluster according \(j\)-th (\(j=1,...,k\)) column \(\).

title: Interpreting factors with bff(), the Best Feature Function
text: notes implementation BFF: Positive skewness. \(D\) document-term matrix (.k.., bags words), holds elements non-negative. However, absolutely guarantee \(Y\) non-negative entries. motivates positive-skew transformation, .e., flip signs columns \(Y\) negative sample third moment. Handling negative elements. now, undergo rather ad-hoc solution existence negative elements \(Y\) – pretending little effects. importance calculation, negative weights (\(Y_{ij}<0\)) equally treated \(-1\). words, negative elements result subtractions/reduction/contraction importance metrics. Weight normalization. BFF, utilize \(Y\) matrix way weighting covariates (\(D\)). therefore natrual expect columns \(Y\) (akin ) probability distributions, .e., probability select one member cluster random. Recall also columns \(Y\) (close ) unit \(\ell_2\)-norm. Hence, additional transformation needed: normalized \(Y\) column. particular, done separately positive negative elements. Variance stabilization. model \(I_{lj}\) Poisson rate model \(\text{Poisson}(\lambda_{lj})\), sample mean variance coupled (.e., expectation \(\lambda_{lj}\)). order standardize importance measure \(\), need decouple two statistics. Performing square-root transformation, \(f(x)=\sqrt{x}\), trick; stabilizes sampling variance, becomes nearly constant.

what: Vintage Sparse PCA for Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis
title: Vintage Sparse PCA for Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis
text: goal vsp enable fast, spectral estimation latent factors random dot product graphs. mild assumptions, vsp estimator consistent (degree-corrected) stochastic blockmodels, (degree-corrected) mixed-membership stochastic blockmodels, degree-corrected overlapping stochastic blockmodels. generally, vsp estimator consistent random dot product graphs can written form Z Y satisfy varimax assumptions [1]. vsp works directed undirected graphs, weighted unweighted graphs. Note vsp semi-parametric estimator.

title: Vintage Sparse PCA for Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis
text: can install released version vsp CRAN can install development version vsp :

title: Vintage Sparse PCA for Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis
text: Obtaining estimates vsp straightforward. recommend representing networks igraph objects sparse adjacency matrices using Matrix package. network one formats, can get estimates calling vsp() function. result vsp_fa S3 object.
code: library(Matrix) library(vsp)  library(igraph) data(enron, package = "igraphdata")  enron_fa <- vsp(enron, rank = 30, scale = TRUE) enron_fa #> Vintage Sparse PCA Factor Analysis #>  #> Rows (n):   184 #> Cols (d):   184 #> Factors (rank): 30 #> Lambda[rank]:   0.2077 #> Components #>  #> Z: 184 x 30 [dgeMatrix]  #> B: 30 x 30 [dgeMatrix]  #> Y: 184 x 30 [dgeMatrix]  #> u: 184 x 30 [matrix]  #> d: 30      [numeric]  #> v: 184 x 30 [matrix]

title: Vintage Sparse PCA for Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis
text: Rohe, K. & Zeng, M. Vintage Factor Analysis Varimax Performs Statistical Inference. 2022+. https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.05387. Code reproduce results paper available .

what: Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis via Vintage Sparse PCA — vsp
title: Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis via Vintage Sparse PCA — vsp
Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis via Vintage Sparse PCA — vsp
code: vsp(x, rank, ...)  # S3 method for default vsp(x, rank, ...)  # S3 method for matrix vsp(   x,   rank,   ...,   center = FALSE,   recenter = FALSE,   scale = FALSE,   rescale = FALSE,   tau_row = NULL,   tau_col = NULL,   kaiser_normalize_u = FALSE,   kaiser_normalize_v = FALSE,   rownames = NULL,   colnames = NULL )  # S3 method for Matrix vsp(   x,   rank,   ...,   center = FALSE,   recenter = FALSE,   scale = FALSE,   rescale = FALSE,   tau_row = NULL,   tau_col = NULL,   kaiser_normalize_u = FALSE,   kaiser_normalize_v = FALSE,   rownames = NULL,   colnames = NULL )  # S3 method for dgCMatrix vsp(   x,   rank,   ...,   center = FALSE,   recenter = FALSE,   scale = FALSE,   rescale = FALSE,   tau_row = NULL,   tau_col = NULL,   kaiser_normalize_u = FALSE,   kaiser_normalize_v = FALSE,   rownames = NULL,   colnames = NULL )  # S3 method for igraph vsp(x, rank, ..., edge_weights = NULL)

title: Semi-Parametric Factor Analysis via Vintage Sparse PCA — vsp
text: x Either graph adjacency matrix, igraph::igraph tidygraph::tbl_graph. x matrix Matrix::Matrix x[, j] correspond edge going node node j. rank number factors calculate. ... Ignored. center adjacency matrix row column centered? Defaults FALSE. recenter varimax factors re-centered around original factor means? used center = TRUE, defaults FALSE. scale regularized graph laplacian used instead raw adjacency matrix? Defaults TRUE. center = TRUE, first centered normalized. rescale regularized graph laplacian used instead raw adjacency matrix? Defaults TRUE. center = TRUE, first centered normalized. tau_row Row regularization term. Default NULL, case use row degree. Ignored scale = FALSE. tau_col Column regularization term. Default NULL, case use column degree. Ignored scale = FALSE. kaiser_normalize_u Whether use Kaiser normalization rotating left singular vectors U. Defaults FALSE. kaiser_normalize_v Whether use Kaiser normalization rotating right singular vectors V. Defaults FALSE. rownames Character vector row names x. row names propagated row names U Z. Defaults NULL. colnames Character vector column names x. column names propagated row names V Y. Defaults NULL. edge_weights x igraph::igraph, edge attribute use form weighted adjacency matrix.

title: Perform varimax rotation on a low rank matrix factorization — vsp.svd_like
code: library(LRMF3) library(RSpectra)  s <- svds(ml100k, k = 2) mf <- as_svd_like(s) fa <- vsp(mf, rank = 2)
